As an HM grad (1980) this doesn't really surprise me. Tek was a good teacher and inspired lots of kids. There was a certain amount of myth making he engaged in, sure.
But the 1970s-1980s were a very different time. And HM, which had transitioned from all-male to coed during my time there, still maintained a lot of the single sex school ethos. The kids involved were not naifs. They were sophisticated people raised in intellectual households. They knew what they were doing.
Does that make what the teachers did right? No. But it is not fair to judge the situation from 30 years' later perspective.

Horace Mann needs to own it. We, who went there, need to be unequivocal in our condemnation. I have been thinking about my classmates who, during our time there, changed for the worse, grew silent, came to sad endings. I am haunted by the possibility that horrific things happened that harmed them that I did not know how to recognize or help prevent.

@ "'In those days, it was very spontaneous and casual, and it did not seem really wrong,' he said."

In the early 1980s? Gimme a break! I was in college in the early 1980s, and I remember the era well. This was *years* after the second wave of the women's rights movements started, *years* after the gay rights movement started; shortly before the publication of books like "The Courage to Heal." It was actually something of a high-water mark for cultural awareness of the reality and prevalence of child abuse, before people overreacted to the problem of "false memory syndrome" and the pendulum swung back toward sweeping child abuse under the rug. The early '80s were hardly the dark ages of the early 1960s (when I was a preschooler), when no one talked about child abuse except for the standard "don't take candy from strangers" and kids whispering horror stories to each other.

Lin's statement is outrageous on its face. Maybe it didn't seem wrong to *Lin,* but that's just par for the course for child abusers, many of whom take the position that sex with an adult is good for children; that children actively seek them out, "seduce" them and initiate sexual contact; that they truly love the children they exploit (and usually soon move on from), etc., ad nauseam.

Throw the creep in jail. Where's the Bronx DA? If the perp wants to plead guilty, all the better.

My family is still recovering from the shock of Mr Lin's confessions. My sister was a student at HM and Lin was her private English tutor (with lessons in the basement no less!) for the better part of a year. My sister is disappointed in his personal flaws because she too remembers a masterful teacher and spiritual soul. My mother is reeling with the knowledge that she allowed her teenage daughter to be alone for hours in her basement with a man whom she thought she could trust. My father  always felt Lin was a little off. I too remember Lin as a man everyone revered. He was soft spoken, seemingly gentle,  and if you were not schooled in Buddhism you might think he was a little off.   But when my sister called me late last night to give me the heads up on this article and to express her "disappointment" I being a middle/high school teacher for the past 22 years, had to immediately correct her. Mr Lin was a sexual predator. He used his power, authority and his students' reverence  as a means to gain what he wanted - sex- with those he was mandated to protect - his under age students. To think those young men have no effects from these "cuddle" sessions is to further traumatize them. If any good at all can come from this admission perhaps it is highlighting the fact that there is a statute of limitations for acts committed by sexual predators. As is the case with Sandusky, Mr Lin should also be in a jail cell this evening.

Brilliant, Profressor Krugman. Sadly, individual interests trump lessons of history. How can we get the message through: how can we move the powers that be to intelligent action? We are all citizens of the world, yet we abdicate our futures to the people who have little interest in those futures: human condition goes against their individual interests. With the current scenario, fueling division and old reflexes to economic hardship are finding scapegoats to hate, (such as immigrants), the situation is leading to the kind of frustration and potential violence the world can little suffer to relive. We owe it to children to prevent them living the human tragedies of the past, don't we?
Very sad. But can a true apology start with an "if "?

Never an HM student, when I was a senior in high school, I met Tek Lin in 1970 at an extra-curricular conference for private school students where he led a discussion group. Through college and later, I spent probably 40 nights at Tek's house in all seasons and different conditions of life. While my parents weren't paying tuition to HM and he had no formal pedagogic authority over me, the relationship was clearly one of teacher-student, including elements of impressionability and emotional vulnerability. I was at that time regularly approached by gays which presumably demonstrated some desirability to that orientation.

Tek Young Lin's conduct was at all times and in all lights absolutely impeccable, humane, and beyond reproach without any trace of sexual manipulation or impropriety. Nor was there any sexual contact. Having attended 3 ultra-elite universities over 9 years, I'd vouch that Tek's a singularly gifted teacher and life instructor with insights and experiences that one would be hard pressed to find in the arid, self-serving, and spineless ecosystems of most higher education. His stories of his HM students whom I never met provided fully persuasive evidence of his concern for their well-being and development. My life was enriched by the "serendipity" of our initial encounter.

To spare the knee-jerk reaction of other commentators, to any coherent mind, this testimony in no way transmutes or re-characterizes the facts alleged in the article.

DW: You have taken that sentence utterly out of context. As such, I believe you've missed the point.

The context here is not whether "adults in power relationships over children" are inherently coercive (a matter not in dispute), but whether/ how the power and coercion held by priests differs from the power and coercion held by teachers (and whether due to that difference or other reader biases, the NYT readers' reactions have differed).

My second sentence should make clear that (in response to Brenda Becker), people's reactions to the different circumstances of priest-parishioner and teacher-student sexual abuse may relate to the "fuzzy" difference (i.e., different by matters of degree) between the powers inherent in the two professions and whether students feel they have recourse to safely avoid and report their abuser.

I agree that adults are almost always in power relationships over children. Further, that sexual relationships and sexual favors should be forbidden between those with grossly inequal power, as the nature of the coercion may be inescapable and irrefutable. But, that question was never in dispute.
